channel.title: undefined - Dietrich Ayala
channel.description: Internet freedom, the web and Mozilla.

item.title: Seth (Session 51)
item.description: Your life, believe it or not, basically, is a simultaneous happening. You merely see it in slow motion. ~ Seth (Sess.51)Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: John Robb of Userland Software, on Pessimism
item.description: "No sense being pessimistic. It wouldn't work anyway."Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: Andrei Zmievski, PHP Developer
item.description: "Programming is an art form that fights back."Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: Andrew Layman on Serialization of Null Values (SOAPBuilders)
item.description: "If you open up a cupboard and don't find a bicycle, are the cupboard's contents different than if you opened it and didn't find an elephant?" - Andrew Layman, during a discussion of techniques for serializing null values in XMLLink
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: Quote from Nicholas Lehuen on xml-dev
item.description: "Building for the future does not necessarely mean we must stick to the past."Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: David McCusker, on writing.
item.description: "(I'm much happier being able to write for a public mode.) I don't think my opinion is worth enough for private ideas. But sharing can make marginal notions almost worthwhile."Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: Old Persian proverb
item.description: Trust in God, but tie your camel.Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: Tim bray, Taxi article on xml.com
item.description: "This is serious; whenever you have people sitting around in front of a machine waiting for it to react, you're practicing bad management, because computers are cheap and people are expensive."Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: Bert Wilson, from Bert's World of Little Known Facts
item.description: "Ratio of the length of toilet paper used annually in the US to the distance between Earth to Uranus : 1:1 "Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: Thomas L. Friedman: Naked Air
item.description: Think about it. If everybody flew naked, not only would you never have to worry about the passenger next to you carrying box cutters or exploding shoes, but no religious fundamentalists of any stripe would ever be caught dead flying nude, or in the presence of nude women, and that alone would keep many potential hijackers out of the skies. It's much more civilized than racial profiling. And I'm sure that it wouldn't be long before airlines would be offering free dry-cleaning for your clothes while you fly.Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: Meg Hourihan (megnut.com) on the Oreilly P2P conference speakers
item.description:
"One of my favorite expressions so far, gleaned from the "Military Applications for P2P" panel yesterday was decision superiority. The armed forces are always looking to gain decision superiority apparently, and now I want to as well. I think that would be really helpful in most situations."

"Another expression used yesterday that I loved came from Cory Doctorow in his "A New Way of Understanding P2P" presentation. He talked about the concept of an imagination proposition, or the idea that people get involved in something simply because it's interesting. An example he stated was the huge number of people involved in SETI@home vs. P2P projects searching for cures for AIDS or cancer. While the value proposition for an AIDS cure is higher than the search for extraterrestrial life, it's simply more interesting to people to dedicate their spare CPU cycles to the search for aliens. Imagination proposition."Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala
